an7.73:1.1: “Once upon a time, mendicants, there was a Teacher called Sunetta. He was a religious founder and was free of sensual desire.
an7.73:1.2: He had many hundreds of disciples.
an7.73:1.3: He taught them the path to rebirth in the company of Brahmā.
an7.73:1.4: Those lacking confidence in Sunetta were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an7.73:1.5: Those full of confidence in Sunetta were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
an7.73:2.1: Once upon a time there was a teacher called Mūgapakkha …
an7.73:2.6: Araka. He was a religious founder and was free of sensual desire.
an7.73:2.7: He had many hundreds of disciples.
an7.73:2.8: He taught them the way to rebirth in the company of Brahmā.
an7.73:2.9: Those lacking confidence in Araka were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an7.73:2.10: Those full of confidence in Araka were—when their body broke up, after death—reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
an7.73:3.2: If someone with malicious intent were to abuse and insult these seven teachers with their hundreds of followers, would they not make much bad karma?”
an7.73:3.5: But someone who abuses and insults a single person accomplished in view with malicious intent makes even more bad karma.
an7.73:3.7: I say that any injury done by those outside of the Buddhist community does not compare with what is done to one’s own spiritual companions.
an7.73:4.1: So you should train like this:
an7.73:4.2: ‘We will have no malicious intent for our spiritual companions.’
